title: I have a judgement against me for 22k from riverwalk holdings regarding a former chase credit card acct how should i deal with?
question: i have read that riverwalk has some questionable practices and want to know how to deal with this the judgement is preventing me from using my credit
answers: The easiest way to deal with it is to file a Chapter 7 bankruptcy and obtain a discharge of all of your debts. If you do not qualify for Chapter 7 then consider a Chapter 13 where you repay part of your debts over time. If you do not want to file bankruptcy then pay the debt.
Counsel's are all correct. You should consult a debt protection attorney and a BK attorney. Feel free to contact our offices for a free consultation on your rights.
Even if you set aside the judgment, the debt will still be there. If you have other debt, you should settle it or file a bankruptcy.

I agree with Atty. Chen - especially if the "questionable practices" you refer to have been related to obtaining default judgments without proper service (which is very common), then you should consult with a local attorney about filing a motion to vacate the judgment and quash the alleged service. The creditor would then have to properly serve you and you would then have a chance to defend the complaint or work out a settlement, but at any rate the judgment would be vacated and would therefore have to be removed from your credit report. The removal of the judgment from your credit report would probably then restore your credit.

A default judgment that was not properly served on the defendant would be invalid. A motion to set aside the judgment for lack of proper service, is typically the recommendation, unless there are so many debts that Bankruptcy is appropriate. Please see my links below which explain the defendant's options upon learning of an invalid default judgment for money and how to get this set aside and that the timing is critical, as the defendant should never sit on it, or the court can deny an untimely motion for unreasonable delays. Also, if you don't set it aside, then the judgment will appear on your credit report for many years, until paid or discharge in Bankruptcy. I'd suggest you contact an a attorney privately to review the court's file in detail and give you a confidential assessment of your options.

You don't indicate whether the judgment was a default judgment (wherein you were either not served with the summons, or you just did not respond after being served with the summons), or whether you actually defended the collection case and lost. If this was a default judgment, you could consider hiring an attorney to make a motion to set aside the default and vacate the default judgment.

If you already have a judgment against you, then the questionable practices would not be relevant. However, you might be able to file a Claim of Exemptions to prevent collection of the judgment. Or you might consider Chapter 7 bankruptcy to discharge the debt.
